hints.content: Start by trimming the input string to remove any leading or trailing spaces. This will help you focus on the actual words without worrying about extra spaces at the ends.
Next, split the trimmed string into individual words. You can use a method that splits by spaces, which will also handle multiple spaces between words.
Count the total number of spaces in the original string. This will be important for redistributing the spaces evenly between the words.
Determine how many words are present in the string. This will help you calculate how many spaces can be placed between them.
If there is only one word, all spaces should be placed at the end of the string. Think about how you would handle this special case.
Calculate the number of spaces that can be placed between the words. This is done by dividing the total spaces by the number of gaps between words (which is the number of words minus one).
After calculating the spaces between words, remember to account for any leftover spaces that cannot be evenly distributed. These should be added to the end of the string.
Construct the final string by joining the words with the calculated number of spaces between them. Ensure that you also append any leftover spaces at the end.
Make sure your final string has the same length as the original input. This means checking that the number of characters matches after rearranging the spaces.
Consider edge cases, such as when there are multiple spaces between words or if there are leading/trailing spaces. Your solution should handle these gracefully.

questionNotes: The input string contains at least one word.
Words are separated by at least one space.
The output string must maintain the same length as the input.
If spaces cannot be evenly distributed, extra spaces go at the end.
